poem:
A Turning in Bolivia  

red-marble dawn,  
streets carry whispers  
of past promises,  
each vote a heartbeat,  
brushing against  
walls of history—  
a nation's pulse,  
between hands,  
trembling, the paper  
thin fate—  
will the river  
of change flow  
right or left,  
or softly  
settle  
into silence?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Bolivians go to polls in election that could end 20 years of socialism Bolivians are going to the polls in an election that could mark a shift to the right – and the end of nearly 20 years of rule by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas). The party, which came to power with the first election of Evo Morales in 2005, risks losing its legal status if it fails to reach 3% – a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
